TextEquiv.Unicode: and in the polver of his Godhead is
present in all places. For therefore did
the Creede adde Almightinesse to this
sitting of his, where it is saide, He
fitteth at the right hande of the father
almightie. And in safnt Matthew the
Lorde sayth, To me is given all might
in heaven, and inearth, goe therefore
and bring al nations unto me.
So then I suppose that briefly thus
I have well declared what manner of
place heaven is, to wit, a place of qui
etnesse, ioy, and everlasting felicitie,
wherein the sonne of God doth sit, doth
dwell, and is in his humanitie, as we
also, that are the memders of Christ,
shalbe in the verie same place without
all dolour and griefe in ioye for ever
more. And although our Lorde be de
livered from all grievous businesse,
yet we meane not that he sitteth idle
ly leaning on his elbowes. For he is a
king, a Priest, and verie God in the
verie temple of God : he cannot choose
therefore of his naturall propertie and
office but work salvation in the elect,
and do all things, that lie God a king,
and Priest in hande to doe. So then
nowe we all knowe what our Lorde
doth as he fitteth in heaven. Neither
is it any trouble to him at al to do and
worke that which he doth, for he wor
keth not of compulsion, but naturally
and of his owne accorde,
Thus and no otherwise did the an
cient interpreters of the holie Scrip
tures handle this article of our belief,
Some of whose testimonies I will
here alledge. saint Hierome in his
exposition of Paules first Chapter to
the Ephesians, saith: he hath decla
red the poler of God by the simili
tude of a man: not because a seate is
placed and God the father sitteth ther
on, having his sonne sitting there with
him: but because we cannot other

and in the polver of his Godhead is present in all places. For therefore did the Creede adde Almightinesse to this sitting of his, where it is saide, He fitteth at the right hande of the father almightie. And in safnt Matthew the Lorde sayth, To me is given all might in heaven, and inearth, goe therefore and bring al nations unto me. So then I suppose that briefly thus I have well declared what manner of place heaven is, to wit, a place of qui etnesse, ioy, and everlasting felicitie, wherein the sonne of God doth sit, doth dwell, and is in his humanitie, as we also, that are the memders of Christ, shalbe in the verie same place without all dolour and griefe in ioye for ever more. And although our Lorde be de livered from all grievous businesse, yet we meane not that he sitteth idle ly leaning on his elbowes. For he is a king, a Priest, and verie God in the verie temple of God : he cannot choose therefore of his naturall propertie and office but work salvation in the elect, and do all things, that lie God a king, and Priest in hande to doe. So then nowe we all knowe what our Lorde doth as he fitteth in heaven. Neither is it any trouble to him at al to do and worke that which he doth, for he wor keth not of compulsion, but naturally and of his owne accorde, Thus and no otherwise did the an cient interpreters of the holie Scrip tures handle this article of our belief, Some of whose testimonies I will here alledge. saint Hierome in his exposition of Paules first Chapter to the Ephesians, saith: he hath decla red the poler of God by the simili tude of a man: not because a seate is placed and God the father sitteth ther on, having his sonne sitting there with him: but because we cannot other
wise conceive howe the sonne dooth
judge and reigne, but by such wordes
applyed to our capacitie. As therefore
to be nent to God, or to depart farre
from him is not to be understood ac
cording to the diftance of places, but
after mens merites, because the saints
are heard by him, but the sinnes fof
whome the Prophete saieth, Beholde
they that gette them selves from thee
shall perish lare removed farre enough
for comming neare him at all. Even so
likewise to bee eyther at the right or
left hande of God is to bee taken so,
that the saints are at his right hand and
sinners at his left. As our saviour
him selfe also in the Gospell affirming
the same doeth say, that at the right
hand are the sheepe, and the goates
at the left. Moreover this verie word
to sit) doeth argue the polver of a
kingdome, by which God is benefici
all to them on whom he doeth vou th
safe to sit, in so muth as verilie he doth
rule them, and hath them alwayes in
his guiding, et doth turne to his owne
becke or government, the necks of the
that before ran out of the way at ran
don, and at libertie.
Saint Augustine in his booke De
Fide G. Bymhoso sayth, we beleeve that
he sitteth at the right hande of God
the Father. Tet not so therefore as
though we shoulde thinke that God
the Father is comprehended within
the limittes of a mans bodie : so that
they that thinke of him shoulde ima
gine that hee hath both a right and a
left side: And whereas it is sayde that
the Father sitteth, we must not sup
pose that he doeth sicte with bended
hammes, least peradventure wee fall
into the same sacriledge for which the
Apostle accurseth them that have
chaunged the glorie of the lncorrup
tible God, into the similitude of a cor

wise conceive howe the sonne dooth judge and reigne, but by such wordes applyed to our capacitie. As therefore to be nent to God, or to depart farre from him is not to be understood ac cording to the diftance of places, but after mens merites, because the saints are heard by him, but the sinnes fof whome the Prophete saieth, Beholde they that gette them selves from thee shall perish lare removed farre enough for comming neare him at all. Even so likewise to bee eyther at the right or left hande of God is to bee taken so, that the saints are at his right hand and sinners at his left. As our saviour him selfe also in the Gospell affirming the same doeth say, that at the right hand are the sheepe, and the goates at the left. Moreover this verie word to sit) doeth argue the polver of a kingdome, by which God is benefici all to them on whom he doeth vou th safe to sit, in so muth as verilie he doth rule them, and hath them alwayes in his guiding, et doth turne to his owne becke or government, the necks of the that before ran out of the way at ran don, and at libertie. Saint Augustine in his booke De Fide G. Bymhoso sayth, we beleeve that he sitteth at the right hande of God the Father. Tet not so therefore as though we shoulde thinke that God the Father is comprehended within the limittes of a mans bodie : so that they that thinke of him shoulde ima gine that hee hath both a right and a left side: And whereas it is sayde that the Father sitteth, we must not sup pose that he doeth sicte with bended hammes, least peradventure wee fall into the same sacriledge for which the Apostle accurseth them that have chaunged the glorie of the lncorrup tible God, into the similitude of a cor
